726416f-a.title: Queens: Corona Avenue - 102nd Street
726416f-a.text:
Corona Avenue (tracks thereon) at and adjoining the S.W.
corneo of 102nd Street, showing in four views at the corner of
G. I. Rapelje house (1891), renovated in 1933. Geo. I. Rapelje
was te owner from 1852-1893. E. L. Armbruster states Rapelje
still owned it in 1891. However the Queens Atlas shows that
this hose belonged to one Reed in 1891.
May 1926
Views 1 and 4
View 2\&3: April 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
MAY BE RPPRODUCED.

726420f-d.title: Queens: Corona Avenue - 102nd Street
726420f-d.text:
Corona Avenue, north side, between 1O2nd and 104th Streets,
showing the Geo. W. Burroums house of 1852 to 1873. It was
erected by John Burroughs who died in 1750. Bis sons John and
Joseph inherited the farm. Josephs son Thomas was the next owner.
Pe married Sarah,daughter of George Wyckoff. His son was Geo. Wyckoff
Burroughs and his daughter married Isaac Moe who was the owner in
1923. The house was gone by June 1930. Near this house was once
the Comrmons of Newtown. This place was once General Moore's head-
quarters. It is questionably stated that the house was erected
abot 1700 on the site of the former Wm. Stevenson house that was
acquired, in 1742 by Richard Betts. Jonathan Randel was an
occupant in 1852.
1922
Views 1 and 2
Views 3\&:4rJan. 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

726419f-a.title: Queens: Corona Avenue - 102nd Street
726419f-a.text:
Corona Avenue, (rear view) north side, between 1O2nd and 104th
Streets, showing in three views the Burroughs house. View No. 1
shows the front of the house and the east side; No. 2 shows the rear
and side including Nos. 102-20---102-24 also on the south side of
Corona Avenue. No. 3 shows another rear view with Corona Ave. at the
left.
May 1926
Views 1 and 2
View 3: April 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Uollection
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

726418f-b.title: Queens: Corona Avenue - 102nd Street
726418f-b.text:
Corona Avenue, north side, between 1O2nd and 104th Streets,
showing the Burroughs House, erected by John Burroughs who died
in 1750. The house was once the headquarters of General Moore.
View 1: P. L. Sperr  April 1925
NO REPRODU;TIONS
Views 2 and 3: Eugene L. Armbruster Collection---1923
MAY BE REPRODUCED

726417f-a.title: Queens: Corona Avenue - 102nd Street
726417f-a.text:
Corona Avenue, at the S.W. corner of 1O2nd Street, showing an
old type frame house. Corona Avenue, here, was formerly known as
Newtown Avenue, and 102nd Street as Mulberry Avenue.
P. L. Sperr  June 7, 1927
NO REPRODUCTIONS

725768f-a.title: Queens: 102nd Street - Corona Avenue
725768f-a.text:
102nd Street (left foreground), at the S.W. corner of Corona Ave.
(formerly Newton Ave.), showing the farmhouse of George I. Rapelye
from 1852 to 1873. George I. Rapelye was born in Nova Scotia in 1787.
His father returned to Newtown in 1792. George I. Was still living in
1882. The old number of this house was 60; it is now 9932 Corona Ave.
The house was renovated in 1933, and opened to the public as the New
Cottage Inn in November 1933.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
